1. Introduction
The applications of micro and nano technologies and structures are increasing day by day and this needs vast studies and investigations on micro and nanostructures. The beams have important functional roles as one of the main elements of most of the small-scale systems. Thus, different kinds of behaviors of different nano-/micro-beams should be evaluated for designation. For this purpose, many scientists have put their efforts to analyze the static and dynamic behaviors of micro-beams [1-5] and nano-beams [6-10], etc. Many researchers have focused on vibrational studies on the micro and nano-beams, tubes, etc. Shaat, Khorshidi, Abdelkefi and Shariati [11] studied the vibrational behavior of cracked nano-beams made of nanocrystals. Murmu and Adhikari [12] studied the vibration of doublenanobeam-systems. The vibration of single-walled nanotubes and double-walled nanotubes was studied by Wang and Varadan [13] via elastic beam theories. Togun [14] studied the nonlinear free and forced vibration of nanobeam with attached mass. Askari, Saadatnia and Esmailzadeh [15] studied the nonlinear vibration of nanobeam with the quadratic rational Bezier arc curvature. Liu, Ke, Yang, Kitipornchai and Wang [16] studied the nonlinear vibration behavior of piezoelectric nanoplate. The free and forced vibrations of piezoelectric ceramic circular nanoplates are studied by Wang, Li, Jin and Wang [17]. Hebali, Tounsi, Houari, Bessaim and Bedia [18] introduced a new quasi-3D hyperbolic shear deformation theory for the static and free vibration analysis. Tounsi, Houari and Bessaim [19] presented 3- unknowns non-polynomial plate theory for buckling and vibration of functionally graded sandwich plate. Also, there were other presented theories for study of shear deformation and vibration of plates [20-28]. Functionally graded materials (FGMs) have been the aim of many studies. These days, FG materials are being studied to be applied for different applications such as biomedical [29], implants [30-32], etc. Many researchers have also evaluated the dynamic and vibration behavior of small scale structures made of FGMs. Roque, Martins, Ferreira and Jorge [33] studied the effect of small scale parameter on the vibration of a Timoshenko FG nanobeam. Jia, Ke, Feng, Yang and Kitipornchai [34] studied the free nonlinear vibration behavior of FG micro-beams considering electrostatic and Casimir forces and also temperature change. Using the modified couple stress theory, Al-Basyouni, Tounsi and Mahmoud [35] studied the bending and vibration of FG microbeam. Şimşek [36] investigated the size-dependent nonlinear free vibration of a functionally graded nanobeam based on the nonlocal strain gradient theory. On the basis of the nonlocal differential constitutive relations of Eringen,
Zemri, Houari, Bousahla and Tounsi [37] proposed a nonlocal shear deformation beam theory to study the bending, buckling, and vibration of FG nanobeams. Thai, Vo, Nguyen and Lee [38] studied the size-dependent free vibration characteristics of FG sandwich microbeams. In addition to the mentioned studies, many other studies have been conducted on the mechanical behavior of functionally graded micro and nanosystems [39-42], etc. Also, many studies are served to study the buckling and vibration behavior of FG plate [43-48]. In addition to the functionally graded materials, porous materials are also a new type of material with emerging applications. Thus, these kinds of materials have been the focus of many mechanical studies [49-52]. Besides, similar to the functionally graded materials, the dynamic and vibration of the structures that are made of porous materials are interesting for scientists. Bo [53] studied the vertical vibration of an elastic circular plate on fluid-saturated porous half space. Yamaguchi, Kurosawa and Enomoto [54] performed analysis on the damped vibration behavior of automotive double walls with a porous material using the finite element method (FEM). based on the classical theory of homogeneous plates Leclaire, Horoshenkov and Cummings [55] studied the transverse vibrations of a thin rectangular porous plate saturated by a fluid and also studied the vibrations of a rectangular porous plate Leclaire, Horoshenkov, Swift and Hothersall [56]. Using variational principle, Vashishth and Gupta [57] studied the vibration of anisotropic porous piezoelectric ceramic plates. Altintas [58] studied the vibration behaviors of heterogeneous porous micro materials. Takahashi and Tanaka [59] investigated on a method of theoretical approach of acoustic coupling due to flexural vibration of porous plates made of elasticmaterials. Guastavino and Göransson [60] studied the vibration of anisotropic porous foam materials. Della and Shu [61] studied the vibration of porous beams with embedded piezoelectric sensors and actuators. In addition, porous functionally grade materials are also the aim of many studies. Barati and Zenkour [62] studied the electro-thermo-mechanical vibrational of porous functionally graded piezoelectric plates by a refined four-variable plate theory. Also, there are also studies on Although there have been a lot of studies on FG and AFG micro/nanobeams, there has never been a study on the vibration behavior of two-dimensional functionally graded (2D-FG) porous micro or nanobeams. So, in this study we present the vibrational analysis on thess structures considering the effect of FG power indexes along length (nx) and thickness (nz). The governing equations are derived using Eringen’s nonlocal theory for nanobeam and the modified couple stress theory is used to derive the equations of microbeam. The generalized differential quadrature method (GDQM) is utilized to solve the governing equation. Finally,

using an equivalent shear correction factor. The Eringen’s nonlocal elasticity theory defines the stress at a point dependent on the stress at a region around that point [80]. Through this assumption, the nonlocal elasticity theory considers the long range interactions between the points in a model. So, the nonlocal elasticity theory is used in this paper to derive the governing equations of the nanobeam, as it has been used many times to study the behavior of nanostructures, [81-83]. Accordingly, using the Timoshenko beam theory, the general equation of vibration of bi-directional FG nanobeam can be written as [84, 85]:

2.2.2. Modified couple stress theory
The classical couple stress elasticity theory introduced by KOlTER [86] and others including Toupin [87], Mindlin and Tiersten [88] and Mindlin [89] is a higher order continuum theory containing four material constants (two classical and two additional) for isotropic elastic materials. This theory has been used to model the pure bending of a circular cylinder by Anthoine [90]. In addition, other models of beam bending were reported based on other nonlocal elasticity theories. For example, the higher order model for Bernoulli–Euler beams developed by Papargyri-Beskou, Tsepoura, Polyzos and Beskos [91] is based on the gradient elasticity theory with surface energy of Sulem and Vardoulakis [92], which involves four elastic constants (two classical and two non-classical). This strain gradient beam model was studied more by Vardoulakis and Giannakopoulos [93]. The non-local Bernoulli–Euler beam model proposed by Peddieson, Buchanan and McNitt [73] using a constitutive equation based on Eringen [67] also contains two additional material constants. As there are so much difficulties in obtaining the microstructure related length scale parameters (e.g., Yang and Lakes [94], Lam, Yang, Chong, Wang and Tong [95]) it is better to have non-local beam models which only contain one additional material length scale parameter. The modified couple stress theory has recently been introduced by Yang, Chong, Lam and Tong [96], in which the couple stress tensor is symmetric and only one internal material length scale parameter is involved, unlike those in the classical couple stress theory mentioned above. A variational formulation of the modified couple stress theory was proposed by Park and Gao [97]. The microbeam is studied according to the modified couple stress theory proposed by Toupin [87] and Mindlin and Tiersten [88]. This theory considered two sized parameters in the beginning. After that, Yang, Chong, Lam and Tong [98] modified the proposed couple stress theory to a theory which used one size parameter which was named as the modified couple stress theory. The modified couple stress theory, has been utilized for many times to study the behaviors of microstructures. [99-101]. The general nonlinear equation of vibration of bi-directional FG microbeam is based on the modified couple stress theory and Timoshenko beam theory is written as:

4. Numerical result
The evaluation of the vibrational behavior of micro- and nano-beams are performed through illustration of the results using figures and tables. The results are derived for FG, AFG and 2D-FG Timoshenko micro- and nano-beams made of two types of porous material considering the boundary condition as simply-supported (SS), clamped (CC), clampedsimply supported (CS), clamped-free or by another name cantilever (CF). Using the parametric study, the effects of the nonlocal parameter, small scale parameter, porosity volume fraction and L/h are illustrated. For better understanding of the vibrational behavior, the non-dimensional parameters are defined as below:
(22).a0 e a L  
(22).b0 ll h 
(22).c2 4 2c c A L E I    where A, I, μ, l0 and Ψ are the area of cross section, second moment of area, nondimensional nonlocal parameter, non-dimensional small scale (micro scale) parameter and non-dimensional frequency, respectively. The thickness of microbeam is 15 (μm) and the
thickness of the nanobeam is (nm) nanometer. The validity of the derived equations and the solution procedure are shown through the comparison of the results with the results of Wang, Zhang and He [102] in Table. 1. Table. 2 shows the mechanical properties of ceramic (Al2O3) and metal (SUS304) which compose the material of the studied beams in this paper. Fig. 3 shows the non-dimensional frequency of clamped-clamped (CC) local FG and AFG beams made of porous-I and II materials versus the FG (nz) and AFG (nx) power indexes. Fig. 3 shows that increasing the FG and AFG power indexes increase the frequency which is because increasing the nx and nz decrease the stiffness. In addition, it is seen in Fig. 3 that the dependency of the frequency on the FG and AFG power indexes increase with the porosity volume fraction (α), and this is more intense for porous-I, as it is seen that the decrement of the frequency due to the FG or AFG power indexes is so high that when nx≊1 or nz≊1, there is an intersection between the frequencies of different porosity volume fractions. In fact, the effect of the porosity volume fraction on the frequency of the porous-I beams highly depends on nx or nz as in higher values of nx or nz, the frequency decreases with the increment of α but when nx or nz are low, the increment of α increases the frequency. Comparison between Fig. 3 (a) and (b), respectively with Fig. 3 (c) and (d) shows that when nx or nz are low, the non-dimensional frequency of porous type 1 is higher than that on porous type 2. But, in higher values of nx or nz it is vice versa.

Fig. 3. Non-dimensional natural frequency of local clamped (CC) FG and AFG beams versus nx and nz when L/h=15.
Fig. 4 shows the non-dimensional frequency of clamped FG and AFG porous II micro and nanobeams versus the small scale effects for different values of nx and nz when L/h is 15. It is seen that the micro-scale effect (l0) increases the frequency cause it increases the stiffness and the nano-scale (µ) decreases the frequency as the nanolocal parameter (µ) decreases the stiffness of the nanobeam. Besides, it is seen that as the value of nx and nz increases, the frequency decreases, since increasing the FG and/or AFG power indexes decrease the stiffness of the nano-/micro-beams. It should be noted that the behavior of the SS and CS micro-/nanobeams was the same as CC boundary condition. Thus, to prevent the repetition, we did not add figures of those boundary conditions. Fig. 4. Non-dimensional natural frequency of porous II micro and nano clamped (CC) 2D-FG beams versus nx and nz when L/h=15.
Fig. 5 shows the non-dimensional frequency of cantilever (CF) FG and AFG, perfect and porous nanobeams for different values of nonlocal parameter (µ) versus the FG and AFG power indexes. It is observed that increasing nx and nz decrease the frequency of the nanobeam. It is seen that the non-dimensional frequency of FG nanobeam, increases with the increment of the nonlocal value. But the effect of the nonlocal parameter on the nodimensional frequency of the AFG nanobeam is complicated. When nx is low, increasing the nonlocal value increases the frequency of the nanobeam, while when n is more, the frequency decreases with the increment of the nonlocal value. The reason is that when the nonlocal value is high, the effect of the AFG power index is very intense but as the nonlocal value decreases, the dependency of the frequency of AFG nanobeam on the AFG power index decreases.

Table. 3 depicts the value of non-dimensional natural frequency of perfect and porous CC local, micro and nanobeams in different values of nx and nz. The non-dimensional frequency of CC micro and nanobeams increases with the increment of L/h. Table. 3 shows that increasing the value of nx and nz decrease the non-dimensional frequency which is because the FG and AFG power indexes decrease the stiffness of the beams. It is also observed that increasing each of the FG or AFG power indexes, decrease the effect of the other one. Moreover, when nx=nz=0, the value of the frequencies of the perfect beams and porous II beams are always more than type 1. But, by increasing nx or nz, the frequencies of perfect and type 2 beams become higher than type 1. Besides, the frequency of porous II is always more than the frequency of perfect beams. Besides, it is seen that the frequency of local beams is lower than micro-beams and higher than nanobeams.

In addition, Table. 3, Table. 4 and Table. 5 show that the non-dimensional frequency of local
beam is lower than microbeam and higher than nanobeam. This is because the small scale effect increases the stiffness of the microbeam. On the other hand, the nonlocal parameter reduces the stiffness and so, decreases the non-dimensional frequency of the nanobeam.

sections.heading: Conclusion:
sections.text:
This paper was served to study the vibration of two-dimensional imperfect functionally graded (2D-FG) micro and nanobeams made two types of porous materials. As a novelty of this work, the material is considered to be 2D-FG on the basis of power law with porosity. The nano-scale beam was studied using the Eringen’s nonlocal elasticity and the microbeam was studied by the modified couple stress theory. Utilizing the generalized differential quadrature method (GDQM), the governing equations are solved to obtain the nondimensional frequency. The effects of small scale parameter, nonlocal parameter, L/h, nx, nz, and porosity volume fraction (α) are studied on the vibrational behavior of the nano and microbeams. The main important results are as below:
 Increment of the porosity volume fraction (α) of types I and II, the frequency of local, micro and nanobeams increases.  The effect of the porosity volume fraction (α) on the non-dimensional frequency of local clamped porous-I depends on the nz and nx.
 Increment of nx and nz decreases the non-dimensional frequency as the FG and AFG
power indexes decrease the stiffness.
 Increasing one of FG or AFG power indexes (nz or nx) decreases the effect of the
other one.
 The non-dimensional frequency of local beam is lower than microbeam and higher
than nanobeam as the stiffness of local beam is lower than microbeam and higher than that of nanobeam.
 When the value of nz and nx are both set to be zero, the non-dimensional frequency of
porous type-I is higher than porous type-II and perfect beams and the nondimensional frequency of porous II is always higher than perfect beams.
 Increasing the L/h increases the non-dimensional frequency.
 The non-dimensional frequencies of SS beams are lower than CS. As the degree of
freedom of SS boundary condition are more than CS.

sections.heading: Highlights
sections.text:
For the first time, the vibration of two dimensional functionally graded (2D-FG)
micro-/ and nano-scale beams are investigated.
 For the first time, the vibration of imperfect 2D-FG porous micro- and nano-beams is
considered based on the Eringen's elasticity and the modified couple stress theories.
 Effects of nonlocal parameter (μ), small-scale parameter (l0), FG gradient index along
length (nx) and thickness (nz), type of porosity and porosity volume fraction (α) are studied.
